title: General Paper FQE (Jan 2024)
description: Complete Final Qualifying Examination General Paper from January 2024. Contains 49 questions covering Nursing Education, Research, Pediatrics, and Mental Health.

questions.question: In teaching and learning, curriculum plays a key role in achievement of program/course goals. As a community health nurse when developing content, what would you consider 'core content' to include:

options.text: Content that must be included for achievement of competences
Knowledge, skills and professional qualities that learners would find relevant to their learning needs
Nice to know content which includes subject matter that facilitates performance in different working environments
Content that can be accessed in textbooks by lecturers only and disseminated to students

questions.explanation: Core content refers to the essential, 'must-know' material that is strictly necessary for a student to achieve the required competencies of the profession.

questions.question: Match the evaluation concepts with their definitions:

pairs.right: On-going assessment of students while the course is in progress
Measurement of student abilities during and after participation in a course
Assigning grades for students' achievement at the end of a course

questions.explanation: Formative is ongoing; Assessment is the measurement process; Summative is final grading.

questions.question: The cardinal triggers that would lead you to suspect Sickle cell crisis in a child include:
questions.explanation: Infection, dehydration, and haemolysis (or conditions causing hypoxia/acidosis) are primary triggers for vaso-occlusive crisis.

questions.question: While assessing children with chest infection, you would suspect a child has severe croup (LTB) if they present with:

options.text: A stridor only when at rest
Rapid breathing and chest in drawing

questions.explanation: Stridor at rest indicates significant upper airway obstruction and is a sign of severe croup.

questions.question: Congenital malformations can be detected and corrected early. As a nurse you would suspect Oesophageal atresia or trachea-oesophageal fistula when there is:

options.text: Excessive amount of frothing saliva in the mouth

questions.explanation: Infants with esophageal atresia cannot swallow saliva, leading to accumulation and frothing.

questions.question: In neonatal resuscitation, the sequence of chest compressions to ventilation you would apply is:
questions.explanation: The standard ratio for neonatal resuscitation is 3 compressions to 1 breath.

questions.question: Bronchiectasis is defined as:

options.text: Collection of serous fluid in the pleural cavity
A permanent dilatation of the bronchi and bronchioles resulting from obstruction or infection
A serious illness characterized by inflammation of the bronchioles causing severe dyspnoea
Infection of the lung parenchyma which may be primary or secondary to acute bronchitis or bronchiolitis

questions.explanation: Bronchiectasis involves irreversible widening (dilation) of the bronchial airways.

questions.question: A congenital abnormality which presents with pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, right ventricular hypertrophy and overriding aorta is referred to as:
questions.explanation: These are the four classic defects of Tetralogy of Fallot.

questions.question: Different types of vitamins provide protection to children. When a child is diagnosed with deficiency of vitamin D the likely condition thy would likely develop is:
questions.explanation: Vitamin D deficiency in growing children leads to Rickets. (Osteomalacia is in adults).

questions.question: Acute diarrhea in children is a common cause of death. The common bacteria you would take care to eliminate and ensure they don't affect the child would include:
questions.explanation: E. coli, Shigella, and Salmonella are the primary bacterial causes of acute gastroenteritis/dysentery.

questions.question: Hepatitis A can be prevented:

options.text: By improving food, water and personal hygiene and environmental sanitation
Through administration of hepatitis B vaccine
By avoiding contamination with infected blood or its products
Limiting the use of potentially dangerous blood derivatives

questions.explanation: Hepatitis A is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, so sanitation and hygiene are key prevention strategies.

questions.question: A child with sickle cell disease in vaso-occlusive crisis will present with:

options.text: Obstruction of micro-circulation in the lungs from venous occlusion by sickle cells
Transient and self-limiting bone marrow failure following a severe infection
Obstruction of splenic outflow by sickled cells
Painful bones such as the femur, tibia and lower vertebrae

questions.explanation: Vaso-occlusive crisis typically presents as severe pain (pain crisis) in long bones due to ischemia.

questions.question: Indicate whether the following statements regarding research definitions are TRUE. (Select all that apply)

options.text: A sampling frame is a list, directory or index of cases from which a sample can be selected
The discrepancy between sample characteristics and the population characteristics is referred to as sampling error
A sampling frame is the method used to analyze data
Sampling error refers to mistakes made during data entry

questions.explanation: Both original statements A and B are True definitions.

questions.question: Sampling in research increases confidence in evidence based practice. To sample the population in a Purposive sampling method the researcher:

options.text: Sampling where every Kth case in the population frame is selected for inclusion in the sample
Placing numbers in a container and allowing members of the accessible population to pick any number at random
When it is not possible to obtain a sampling frame because the population is either very large or scattered over a large geographical area
Where cases or subjects are handpicked because they are informative or they possess the required characteristics

questions.explanation: Purposive sampling involves judgmental selection of participants who possess specific characteristics needed for the study.

questions.question: You have decided to sample a population and selected non-probability sampling methods. The main ones would include:
questions.explanation: Purposive, convenient, and snowball are all non-probability methods. The other options contain probability methods (random, stratified, cluster).

questions.question: A dependent variable is one that:

options.text: Affects outcome of a research study either because the researcher is not aware of its existence or does not have control over it
Attempts to indicate the total influence arising from the effects of an independent variable
A researcher manipulates in order to determine its effect or influence on another variable
Converts what was thought of as a positive relationship into a negative relationship and vice versa

questions.explanation: The dependent variable is the outcome/effect that changes in response to the independent variable.

questions.question: Ratio scale is a measurement scale that:

options.text: Groups subjects into categories and ranks them into some order
Assigns numerals to each measure and ranks them in an order with intervals between numerals equally
Has all the characteristics of the other scales with an additional true zero point hence all mathematical operations can be applied to yield meaningful values
Groups subjects or cases from the sample into categories into common sets of characteristics e.g. sex, race etc.

questions.explanation: Ratio scales have a true zero point (e.g., weight, height).

questions.question: Construct validity refers to:

options.text: A measure of the degree to which a research instrument yields consistent results after repeated trials
A measure of the degree to which a research instrument meaningfully and accurately reflects or represents a theoretical concept
A measure of degree to which data collected using a particular instrument represents a specific domain of indicators or content of a particular concept
The use of a measure in assessing subjects' behavior in specific situations

questions.explanation: Construct validity ensures the test measures the theoretical construct it claims to measure.

questions.question: The Hawthorne effect refers to a situation where:

options.text: Subjects' awareness of being in an experimental group motivates them to perform better
A chemically inactive substance with the same colour and taste as the true drug are given to half the patients to determine significant difference between the two groups
The subjects perform much better because of the researcher's expectation
The researcher ratings are influenced by his/her initial impression of the subject

questions.explanation: The Hawthorne effect describes behavior modification due to the awareness of being observed.

questions.question: You wish to analyze data using measures of central tendencies. To determine the median in data you would consider:

options.text: The most commonly attained measurement or value
The 50th percentile in a group of scores
The average of a set of scores or measurements
The distribution of scores around a particular central score or value

questions.explanation: The median is the middle value (50th percentile).

questions.question: Variance refers to:

options.text: The difference between the highest and the lowest score in a distribution
The extent to which scores in a distribution deviate from their mean or average
The sum of each squared deviation divide by the degrees of freedom
The dispersion of scores around the mean of the distribution

questions.explanation: Variance is calculated as the sum of squared deviations from the mean divided by degrees of freedom.

questions.question: You have been assigned as a research supervisor to some students attached to your area of work. They seek to understand what should be contained in the research methodology chapter. How would you advise them?

options.text: Details of the gap or gaps that exist in the area of study and presents the rationale for the study
Researcher's critique of findings from other studies done in related areas
Details regarding the procedures used in conducting the study
Method of the systematic data analysis during the study

questions.explanation: Methodology details the procedures, design, sampling, and tools used.

questions.question: Serial seven tests provide a general summary of
questions.explanation: Serial sevens specifically test concentration and attention, which are part of general cognitive function.

questions.question: A condition in which a patient invents new words/phrases and gives new meaning to the standard words is called:
questions.explanation: Neologisms are newly coined words often seen in schizophrenia.

questions.question: A motor activity disturbance where a patient can maintain an odd position for a long period is called:
questions.explanation: Waxy flexibility (cerea flexibilitas) is a symptom of catatonia.

questions.question: Mental illness that manifests itself with physical symptoms is called:
questions.explanation: Somatic symptom disorder involves extreme focus on physical symptoms causing distress.

questions.question: A misinterpretation of a real stimuli is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Illusions are misinterpretations of actual external stimuli (e.g., seeing a rope as a snake).

questions.question: A patient is said to lack insight when he/she:

options.text: Does not know that he/she is sick and needs help
Knows his problem and does not need help
Knows his problem and needs help

questions.explanation: Insight is the awareness of one's condition and the need for treatment.

questions.question: Fetishism refers to a sexual disorder:

options.text: In which sexual arousal and gratification are brought about by objects such as shoes, underwear or toilet articles
Characterized by recurrent and persistent cross-dressing for the purpose of achieving sexual excitement
In which the preferred method of sexual stimulation and gratification consists of repetitive acts of exposing the genitalia to strangers
In which the preferred method of sexual gratification consists of repetitive observation of people in different stages of undress or sexual activity

questions.explanation: Fetishism involves sexual arousal from non-living objects.

questions.question: You have prepared a lesson for new nursing students. For your teaching to be effective you should organize the content from:
questions.explanation: Effective teaching moves from Concrete (tangible) to Abstract (conceptual), Simple to Complex, Known to Unknown.

questions.question: You are teaching students on human resource concepts. In your definition of job description, you would tell them it refers to:

options.text: tasks or duties a student is required to perform in their daily clinical placement
An outline that focuses on the minor responsibilities of a professional
duties or tasks professionals are expected to perform in future
the roles the trainee is expected to perform in future

questions.explanation: A job description outlines current duties and responsibilities.

questions.question: In the cognitive domain objectives are ordered as follows:

options.text: Application, comprehension, analysis, evaluation, simple knowledge, synthesis
Simple knowledge, comprehension, application, analysis, synthesis, evaluation
Simple knowledge, application, comprehension, analysis, synthesis, evaluation
Evaluation, synthesis, analysis, application, comprehension, simple knowledge

questions.explanation: Bloom's taxonomy order: Knowledge -> Comprehension -> Application -> Analysis -> Synthesis -> Evaluation.

questions.question: The criterion or standard in an educational objective that:

options.text: Describes what the learner is expected to do
Describes the activity to be undertaken
Indicates the condition under which the activity is to be undertaken
Refers to the level of performance or accuracy of doing the activity

questions.explanation: The criterion specifies how well the learner must perform (accuracy/standard).

questions.question: As a clinical instructor, you need to teach nurse students on how to draw and administer medication. Which appropriate teaching method would you go for?
questions.explanation: Demonstration is best for psychomotor skills.

questions.question: Teaching and learning strategies used in the clinical setting include:

options.text: Return demonstration, clinical rounds, role play.

questions.explanation: Case conferences and rounds are specific to clinical settings.

questions.question: Multiple choice question stem must:

options.text: Be stated in positive and not negative
Be dependent on others on the test.

questions.explanation: Stems should be positively stated to avoid confusion.

questions.question: Lecture method is appropriate:

options.text: For training skills when the teacher has mastered the steps.
When material is readily accessible in textbooks and learners are proactive.
When the group is large and there is competition for attention
When time is limited and content is extensive.

questions.explanation: Lectures efficiently cover extensive content in limited time for large groups.

questions.question: A physician prescribes haloperidol (Haldol) to treat the Tourette's syndrome and you provide the child and parents with information about significant side effects. Besides involuntary tremors, which other side effect would you advise the family to anticipate?
questions.explanation: Haldol causes Extrapyramidal Symptoms (EPS) including dystonia (muscle spasms).

questions.question: You are approached by some parents that they are concerned their child's self-esteem may be jeopardized because of peer ridicule. Which suggestion would you offer the parents in this situation?
questions.explanation: Praising genuine accomplishments builds competence and self-esteem (Industry vs Inferiority).

questions.question: A 13-year-old student takes a gun to school and murders a teacher. On the basis of the principles of crisis intervention, when is the best time to provide assistance to those most affected by this incident?
questions.explanation: Crisis intervention should be immediate to process trauma and prevent PTSD.

questions.question: To achieve competences in a clinical setting several teaching methods can be utilized. Select the valid student roles in problem based learning.

options.text: Self-directed study to research the problem
Sharing gathered information with the group
Waiting for the teacher to provide all solutions

questions.question: State five (5) characteristics of the SPICES approach in teaching/learning that you would apply while preparing learners in a college.
Explain three (3) preventive measures you would utilize to prevent and control neonatal tetanus.
As a nursing student outline four (4) key clinical evaluations for a child to be undertaken that would indicate ingestion of a poisonous substance.

options.text: History of sudden onset in healthy child
Respiratory distress or unusual breath odors

questions.question: You have embarked on a study to determine the factors associated with abuse of alcohol among the youth. Explain three (3) reasons why you would undertake literature review.

options.text: To identify gaps in current knowledge

questions.question: Outline four (4) benefits you would get by carrying out a pilot study.

options.text: Test reliability and validity of tools

questions.question: Explain three (3) classifications of Schizophrenia.
A young female has been reported to have attempted suicide. Formulate five (5) questions that you may use to evaluate her suicide risk.

options.text: Do you currently have thoughts of harming yourself?
Do you have a specific plan?
Do you have access to means (e.g. pills)?
Have you ever attempted suicide before?
What stops you from acting on these thoughts?

questions.question: Case Study: Mr. G, 17 years old, brought by police for shouting/threatening traffic, claiming to be police. Excited, interrupting. Diagnosis: Bipolar (Mania). Select the correct management steps.

richContent.content: Case: Mr. G (17yo) brought by police. Behavior: Shouting, threatening, directing traffic, grandiosity (claiming to be police), excited, interrupting. History: Second episode, parents unable to manage.

options.text: Admission: Involuntary (Sectioning) due to risk to self/others
Immediate Safety: Nurse in low-stimulus environment, remove harmful objects
Pharmacology: Administer antipsychotics (e.g. Haloperidol) and Mood Stabilizers (Lithium)
Nutrition: Provide high-calorie finger foods and fluids
Communication: Use firm, calm, short sentences; do not argue with delusions
Admission: Voluntary admission as he is cooperative

questions.explanation: Mr. G presents with acute mania and poses a danger to himself (traffic) and others. Management involves involuntary admission, rapid tranquilization/stabilization, safety measures, and addressing physical needs like nutrition/sleep.
